Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Sensitive Nanoscintillators for Multiplexed Detection of Radioisotopes
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of core-shell nanomaterials for sensitive detection of low-energy radioisotopes commonly used as molecular labels and tracers in quantitative biological, chemical and environmental studies. These nanomaterials can be used in place of traditional methods for measuring low-energy radioisotopes and offer greater sensitivity and better sample compatibility, while also resulting in less hazardous waste. The technology platform is expected to demonstrate several advantages over other methods in particularly challenging, information-rich areas of research, including detection of molecules within living cells. The nanomaterials platform, with further development, will also allow for the simultaneous detection of multiple compounds, an important factor in the study of complex biological samples. These advances will provide critical new tools for bioscience research.<br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will improve the sensitivity of a novel core-shell nanomaterial platform and develop a basic template for multi-color, multiplexed assays as well as an accompanying first-generation instrument capable of translating these advances to commercial application. Radioisotope labels remain the gold standard in a wide range of quantitative biological, chemical and environmental studies and have played a critical role in the investigation of biological systems for almost a century. However, the low energy and short penetration depth of the most commonly used radioisotopes necessitate the use of liquid scintillation counting, solid scintillation counting or scintillation proximity assays for detection. These assays are often incompatible with living systems, are not readily multiplexed and/or provide limited time-resolved measurement capabilities. The goals of this project are: 1) advance nanomaterial preparation to yield higher reproducibility and sensitivity signals; 2) yield multicolor materials for simultaneous multiplexed assays; and, 3) generate a dual color scintillation counter than enables and demonstrates the utility of the platform for multiplexed assays. These goals will be accomplished by exploring a variety of scintillant fluorophores and polymer linkages in parallel with instrument design.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were formulated to address the lack of advancement in the detection of biologically relevant radioisotopes. Low energy radioisotopes are commonly used as molecular labels and tracers in a wide range of biological, chemical and environmental assays, and remain the most sensitive method for detecting low abundance analytes. However, the low energy and short penetration depth of commonly used radioisotopes necessitate the use of liquid scintillation counting (LSC), solid scintillation counting (SSC) or scintillation proximity assays (SPA) for detection. For the most part, these assays are incompatible with living systems and/or provide limited time-resolved measurement capabilities. Scintillation Nanotechnologies Inc. (SNT) is developing a series of core-shell nanomaterial scintillator platforms that overcomes several key limitations of existing radioisotope detection including incompatibility with aqueous and/or living systems and the inability to measure multiple analytes at the same time. We expect that once fully developed, the platform will provide several advantages over other methods for monitoring a wide range of analytical targets using radioisotope labels and will rapidly fill critical needs in the radioisotope detection market including detection in living cells and multiplexed detection directly in the same aqueous samples. This project focused on three key areas of innovation to significantly expand the potential of nanoscintillator materials: 1) advancing nanoparticle preparation to yield higher reproducibility and sensitivity signals; 2) preparing multicolor materials for simultaneous multiplexed assays; and, 3) preparing a first generation instrumentation than enables and demonstrates the utility of nanoscintillators for multiplexed assays.

During this project, five functionalized scintillant fluorophores were synthesized in amounts sufficient for testing. After the functionalized scintillant fluorophores were incorporated into polymer core nanoparticles, emission wavelength, efficiency, degree of incorporation, and scintillant fluorophore leakage were assessed and compared to non-functionalized versions of the same scintillant fluorophores. In addition, at least one, and possibly three scintillant fluorophores that can potentially be used to make nanomaterials with emissions at wavelengths longer than 450 nm have been identified. These emission wavelengths are in addition to the ?blue? that SNT currently produces and the ?red? currently available in the SNT lab. Furthermore, a dual-color scintillation counter has been developed and assembled, and has undergone initial testing.

Radioisotopes play vital roles in a wide range of quantitative biological, chemical and environmental studies, where radioisotope labels have proven to be particularly advantageous for detection of molecules that are present at very low concentrations, and that cannot be detected using other laboratory measurements. The nanoparticle-based assays developed by SNT present several advantages compared to other methods for detecting small molecules, including a) enhanced compatibility with aqueous samples; b) a high-surface area to volume (SA/V) ratio to enhance RI detection; c) an easily modified surface for attachment of biomolecules and other chemical species; and d) a small size that minimizes sample disruption. The capabilities that will be enabled by this research project will significantly affect the ability of our customers to perform novel biochemical assays that will impact many areas of biology and biochemistry.  Additionally, the scintillant nanomaterials developed here will have a significant, positive environmental impact in that they can replace traditional scintillation cocktails which are responsible for significant hazardous waste storage and disposal issues.
